warehouses.name: Practice Pack Warehouse: Financial Statement Analysis 26-LI
warehouses.code: Practice Pack Warehouse: Financial Statement Analysis 26-LI

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-FRA-Lin-17
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in € millions) about a company:

Cash and cash equivalents 40
Total current assets 125
Total non-current assets 35
Revenue 200

Applying vertical common-size analysis to the company's balance sheet, cash and cash equivalents are:

answerFeedback.31eda0f1-7627-4e72-b584-9bf6af3e6187: Correct because vertical common-size analysis involves stating each balance sheet item as a percentage of total assets. Accordingly, Cash and cash equivalents is stated as a percentage of Total assets = Cash and cash equivalents / (Total current assets + Total non-current assets) = 40 / (125 + 35) = 40 / 160 = 25%.
answerFeedback.4005bafc-186c-431a-910b-bd138558d631: Incorrect because it states Cash and cash equivalents as percentage of Revenue instead of Total assets. Consequently, the calculation becomes Cash and cash equivalents / Revenue = 40 / 200 = 20%. Alternatively, double counting Cash and cash equivalents when calculating Total assets would produce the same result. Consequently, Cash and cash equivalents = Cash and cash equivalents / (Cash and cash equivalents + Total current assets + Total non-current assets) = 40 / (40 + 125 + 35) = 40 / 200 = 20%.
answerFeedback.4744a9de-5708-43be-be07-878bd0e91ef1: Incorrect because it states Cash and cash equivalents as percentage of Total current assets instead of Total assets. Consequently, the calculation becomes Cash and cash equivalents / Total current assets = 40 / 125 = 32%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-FRA-Pitrakkou-09
entry.itemBody: Accounting goodwill arising from acquisitions is:

answerFeedback.0c72057a-7f67-4e54-b3c0-5d3cf223fe08: Correct because under both IFRS and US GAAP, accounting goodwill arising from acquisitions is capitalized. Goodwill is not amortised but is tested for impairment annually. If goodwill is deemed to be impaired, an impairment loss is charged against income in the current period.
answerFeedback.95bb0d9a-fea2-403c-96f1-1f672c56993f: Incorrect because under both IFRS and US GAAP, accounting goodwill arising from acquisitions is capitalized.
answerFeedback.b0394f27-fee5-4804-958a-3c9105d58eb1: Incorrect because under both IFRS and US GAAP, accounting goodwill arising from acquisitions is capitalized. Goodwill is not amortised but is tested for impairment annually. If goodwill is deemed to be impaired, an impairment loss is charged against income in the current period.

choices.itemBody: A. expensed in the period it arises.
B. capitalized and amortized over a finite period.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-FRA-Burke-06
entry.itemBody: A company reporting under US GAAP purchases an equity security issued by another company.  If the equity security represents less than 1% of the outstanding equity of the issuing company and the acquiring company owns no other equity stake in the issuing company, the investment is most likely carried on the acquiring company's balance sheet at:

answerFeedback.b76a4016-3bed-42b4-8419-1fd1be8406e6: Incorrect because under US GAAP, all investments in equity securities (other than investments giving rise to ownership positions that confer significant influence over the investee) are measured at fair value with unrealized holding gains or losses recognized in the income statement.
answerFeedback.ccf34ab0-5803-42a6-8c7c-ef284d233c92: Incorrect because under US GAAP, all investments in equity securities (other than investments giving rise to ownership positions that confer significant influence over the investee) are measured at fair value with unrealized holding gains or losses recognized in the income statement.
answerFeedback.fcec4767-2d04-46cd-99b4-bd027aff2bd0: Correct because under US GAAP, all investments in equity securities (other than investments giving rise to ownership positions that confer significant influence over the investee) are measured at fair value with unrealized holding gains or losses recognized in the income statement.

choices.itemBody: B. fair value with any unrealized holding gains/losses recognized in the income statement.
C. fair value with any unrealized holding gains/losses recognized in other comprehensive income.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04274
entry.itemBody: A copyright, for which an active market exists, has a set finite life and is used in a company's operations over more than one fiscal period. Under U.S. GAAP, this copyright is reported using:

answerFeedback.0645fd3f-7512-4baf-b784-cbf2c066ce78: Correct because, under US GAAP, companies are required to use the cost model to value intangible assets. IFRS allow companies to value intangible assets under a cost model or under a revaluation model. The revaluation model can only be selected when there is an active market for an intangible asset.
answerFeedback.40cb4f09-a4fb-4ba7-b15f-ce056a6b9c7e: Incorrect because the revaluation model is not allowed under US GAAP; however, IFRS permit the use of the revaluation model or the cost model.
answerFeedback.f5bf39b4-da53-49ef-8088-2bc31f57194e: Incorrect because the revaluation model is not allowed under US GAAP; however, IFRS permit the use of the revaluation model or the cost model.

choices.itemBody: C. either the cost or the revaluation model.

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q5

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Goodwill is a long-term asset, and cash and inventories are current assets.

entry.itemBody: All of the following are current assets except:

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q6

feedback.neutral: A is correct. Initially, goodwill is measured as the difference between the purchase price paid for an acquisition and the fair value of the acquired, not acquiring, company’s net assets (identifiable assets less liabilities).

entry.itemBody: The initial measurement of goodwill is most likely affected by:

choices.itemBody: C. the fair value of the acquirer’s assets and liabilities.

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q7

feedback.neutral: B is correct. For financial assets classified as trading securities, unrealized gains and losses are reported on the income statement and flow to shareholders’ equity as part of retained earnings.

entry.itemBody: For financial assets classified as trading securities, how are unrealized gains and losses reflected in shareholders’ equity?

choices.itemBody: B. They flow through income into retained earnings.
C. They are a component of accumulated other comprehensive income.

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q8

feedback.neutral: C is correct. For financial assets classified as available for sale, unrealized gains and losses are not recorded on the income statement and instead are part of other comprehensive income. Accumulated other comprehensive income is a component of shareholders’ equity.

entry.itemBody: For financial assets classified as available for sale, how are unrealized gains and losses reflected in shareholders’ equity?

choices.itemBody: C. They are a component of accumulated other comprehensive income.

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q9

feedback.neutral: A is correct. Financial assets classified as held to maturity are measured at amortized cost. Gains and losses are recognized only when realized.

entry.itemBody: For financial assets classified as held to maturity, how are unrealized gains and losses reflected in shareholders’ equity?

choices.itemBody: C. They are a component of accumulated other comprehensive income.

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q10

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Vertical common-size analysis involves stating each balance sheet item as a percentage of total assets. Total assets are the sum of total liabilities (GBP35 million) and total stockholders’ equity (GBP55 million), or GBP90 million. Total liabilities are shown on a vertical common-size balance sheet as (GBP35 million ÷ GBP90 million) ≈ 39%.

entry.itemBody: A company has total liabilities of GBP35 million and total stockholders’ equity of GBP55 million. Total liabilities are represented on a vertical common-size balance sheet by a percentage closest to:

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q11

feedback.neutral: B is correct. A common-size balance sheet analysis provides information about the composition of the balance sheet and it changes over time. As a result, it can provide information about an increase or decrease in a company’s financial leverage.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following would an analyst most likely be able to determine from a common-size analysis of a company’s balance sheet over several periods?

choices.itemBody: A. An increase or decrease in sales
B. An increase or decrease in financial leverage
C. A more efficient or less efficient use of assets

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q12

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Impairment write-downs reduce equity in the denominator of the debt-to-equity ratio but do not affect debt, so the debt-to-equity ratio is expected to increase. Impairment write-downs reduce total assets but do not affect revenue. Thus, total asset turnover is expected to increase.

entry.itemBody: Defining total asset turnover as revenue divided by average total assets, all else equal, impairment write-downs of long-lived assets owned by a company will most likely result in an increase for that company in:

choices.itemBody: A. the debt-to-equity ratio but not the total asset turnover.
B. the total asset turnover but not the debt-to-equity ratio.
C. both the debt-to-equity ratio and the total asset turnover.

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q13

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The current ratio provides a comparison of assets that can be turned into cash relatively quickly and liabilities that must be paid within one year. The other ratios are more suited to evaluate longer-term concerns.

entry.itemBody: An investor concerned about a company’s ability to meet its near-term obligations is most likely to calculate the:

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q14

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The cash ratio determines how much of a company’s near-term obligations can be settled with existing amounts of cash and marketable securities.

entry.itemBody: The most stringent test of a company’s liquidity is its:

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q15

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The debt-to-equity ratio, a solvency ratio, is an indicator of financial risk.

entry.itemBody: An investor worried about a company’s long-term solvency would most likely examine its:

entry.body:
Consider the common-size balance sheets in Exhibit 1 for Company A, Company B, as well as the industry average.

Exhibit 1Balance Sheet and Industry Average

      Company A   Company B   Industry Average
ASSETS
Current assets            
  Cash and cash equivalents   5   5   7
  Marketable securities   5   0   2
  Accounts receivable, net   5   15   12
  Inventories   15   20   16
  Prepaid expenses   5   15   11
Total current assets   35   55   48
  Property, plant, and equipment, net   40   35   37
  Goodwill   25   0   8
  Other assets   0   10   7
Total assets 100   100   100
LIABILITIES AND SHAREHOLDERS’ EQUITY
Current liabilities            
  Accounts payable   10   10   10
  Short-term debt   25   10   15
  Accrued expenses   0   5   3
Total current liabilities   35   25   28
  Long-term debt   45   20   28
  Other non-current liabilities   0   10   7
Total liabilities   80   55   63
  Total shareholders’ equity   20   45   37
Total liabilities and shareholders’ equity   100   100   100
entry.title: Vignette
CFA2419-R-s06-Q16

feedback.neutral:
C is correct. The presence of goodwill on Company A’s balance sheet signifies that it has made one or more acquisitions in the past. The current, cash, and quick ratios are lower for Company A than for the sector average. These lower liquidity ratios imply above-average liquidity risk. The total debt, long-term debt-to-equity, debt-to-equity, and financial leverage ratios are lower for Company B than for the sector average. These lower solvency ratios imply below-average solvency risk.

Current ratio is (35 ÷ 35) = 1.00 for Company A, versus (48 ÷ 28) = 1.71 for the sector average.
Cash ratio is (5 + 5) ÷35 = 0.29 for Company A, versus (7 + 2) ÷28 = 0.32 for the sector average.
Quick ratio is (5 + 5 + 5) ÷35 = 0.43 for Company A, versus (7 + 2 + 12) ÷28 = 0.75 for the sector average.
Total debt ratio is (55 ÷ 100) = 0.55 for Company B, versus (63 ÷ 100) = 0.63 for the sector average.
Long-term debt-to-equity ratio is (20 ÷ 45) = 0.44 for Company B, versus (28 ÷ 37) = 0.76 for the sector average.
Debt-to-equity ratio is (55 ÷ 45) = 1.22 for Company B, versus (63 ÷ 37) = 1.70 for the sector average.
Financial leverage ratio is (100 ÷ 45) = 2.22 for Company B, versus (100 ÷ 37) = 2.70 for the sector average.

entry.itemBody: Which statement is correct?

choices.itemBody: A. Company A has below-average liquidity risk.
B. Company B has above-average solvency risk.
C. Company A has made one or more acquisitions.

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q17

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The quick ratio is defined as (Cash and cash equivalents + Marketable securities + receivables) ÷ Current liabilities. For Company A, this calculation is (5 + 5 + 5) ÷ 35 = 0.43.

entry.itemBody: The quick ratio for Company A is closest to:

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q18

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The financial leverage ratio is defined as Total assets ÷ Total equity. For Company B, total assets are 100 and total equity is 45; hence, the financial leverage ratio is 100 ÷ 45 = 2.22.

entry.itemBody: The financial leverage ratio for Company B is closest to:

entry.title: CFA2419-R-s06-Q19

feedback.neutral: A is correct. A higher cash ratio reflects lower liquidity risk. The cash ratio is defined as (Cash + Marketable securities) ÷ Current liabilities. Company A’s cash ratio, (5 + 5) ÷ 35 = 0.29, is higher than (5 + 0) ÷ 25 = 0.20 for Company B.

entry.itemBody: Which ratio indicates lower liquidity risk for Company A compared with Company B?

entry.title: ITEM_20180516130
entry.itemBody: Deferred tax liabilities result when:

answerFeedback.a723ce07-efc3-4a3c-9441-e7bc396cbadf: Incorrect because if items of expense are included in financial statement income in earlier periods than those for which taxable income is reported, then the financial statement income and associated reported income tax expense will be less than taxable income and actual income tax payable. A deferred tax liability occurs only in the opposite case, when taxable income and income tax payable are smaller. Deferred tax liabilities result from timing differences between financial statement income and taxable income when taxable income is lower than financial statement income, not higher.
answerFeedback.d2e1fb46-8c59-4358-a5fd-7120c138d8dd: Correct. Deferred tax liabilities result when, for a given period, taxable income and the associated income tax payable are less than the reported financial statement income before taxes and the associated income tax expense.
answerFeedback.e5ca825d-4754-418d-9b31-00edf52e1951: Incorrect because straight-line depreciation methods result in lower depreciation expense than accelerated methods. This approach would produce higher taxable income than financial statement income, with no resulting deferred tax liability.

choices.itemBody: A. taxable income in a period is less than reported financial statement income before taxes.
B. items of expense are included in financial statement income in earlier periods than those for which taxable income is reported.
C. straight-line depreciation methods are used for tax purposes and accelerated methods are employed for financial statement purposes.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516134
entry.itemBody:
Use the following common-size balance sheet information to answer the question below.

Assets Company X Company Y Company Z
Cash and cash equivalents 15.6% 12.0% 2.0%
Marketable securities 3.4% 5.1% 12.0%
Trade and other receivables 10.9% 12.7% 4.8%
Other non-financial assets 14.3% 11.7% 7.4%
Total current assets 44.2% 41.5% 26.2%
 
Goodwill 1.6% 2.2% 28.8%
Intangible assets 17.6% 7.0% 24.0%
Property, plant, and equipment 17.7% 25.3% 8.2%
Other financial assets 12.4% 24.0% 9.6%
Other non-financial assets 0.3% 0.0% 2.1%
Deferred tax assets 6.2% 0.0% 1.1%
Total non-current assets 55.8% 58.5% 73.8%
 
Total assets 100.0% 100.0% 100.0%
 
Liabilities and shareholders’ equity      
Trade and other payables 3.4% 3.5% 2.1%
Bank loans and other financial liabilities 8.4% 3.2% 6.0%
Other non-financial liabilities 5.0% 11.7% 9.0%
Deferred income 11.8% 9.8% 0.0%
Total current liabilities 28.6% 28.2% 17.1%
Financial liabilities 18.4% 18.3% 17.4%
Other non-financial liabilities 12.8% 5.7% 7.9%
Deferred tax liabilities 2.5% 4.2% 18.6%
Total non-current liabilities 33.7% 27.5% 43.9%
Total liabilities 62.3% 55.7% 61.0%
 
Total shareholders’ equity 37.7% 44.3% 39.0%
Total liabilities and shareholders’ equity 100.0% 100.0% 100.0%

Which company is most likely to have grown through acquisitions?

answerFeedback.2cde36f0-91b4-48a4-b63e-4c8b3ff301b3: Correct. Company Z has the highest percentage of assets in goodwill at 28.8%, with the other companies having much smaller percentages (1.6% for Company X and 2.2% for Company Y). Because goodwill is an asset recognized by acquirers purchasing companies at prices above the fair value of their identifiable assets and liabilities, it is most likely, given the great disparity in goodwill, that of these firms, Company Z has grown through acquisitions.
answerFeedback.858afe8d-4cb2-496d-9fbc-5001585eed9c: Incorrect because Company Y has 2.2% of its total assets allocated to goodwill, which is substantially less than the percentage for Company Z.
answerFeedback.da248287-e9b5-4dc7-9312-073f315ecce5: Incorrect because Company X has 1.6% of its total assets allocated to goodwill, which is substantially less than the percentage for Company Z.
